Name: Shabti of Tarud
Description: Green glazed faience shabti with one horizontal and one vertical line of hieroglyphs arranged as a T on the front, naming the deceased as a woman Tarud born of Ta-amen. The figure holds pick and hoe, with basket over the left shoulder, and wears a plain wig with long lappets, and a long beard of the kind worn by gods. The back pillar bears no inscription. The shabti was a special figure placed in the tomb to carry out any heavy labour required of the tomb-owner in the afterlife. This example is typical of Late Period burials, which included hundreds of shabtis, with one for each day of the 365-day Egyptian year.
